subject: polity
title: Panchayat Raj - Evolution & Constitutional Journey
description: Timeline of Panchayati Raj from Art 40 DPSP to 73rd Amendment and PESA Act - Complete evolution of local self-governance in rural India

events.title: Art 40 DPSP - Constitutional Directive
events.description: Constitution's Article 40 directs State to organize village panchayats and endow them with necessary powers
events.significance: **Foundation of Panchayati Raj** - Constitutional recognition of village self-governance as a DPSP (non-justiciable but fundamental in governance)

details.heading: Key Provisions & Context
points: **Art 40 (Part IV - DPSPs)**: 'The State shall take steps to organize village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government'
**Non-justiciable**: Being a DPSP, not enforceable in court - States not legally bound but morally obligated
**Gandhian influence**: Mahatma Gandhi's vision of 'gram swaraj' (village self-rule) - Decentralized governance at grassroots

**Dr. Ambedkar's opposition**: He was skeptical of village panchayats, famously called villages 'dens of ignorance, narrow-mindedness' - But Constituent Assembly included Art 40 due to Gandhian vision
**State responsibility**: States given freedom to implement - No uniform structure mandated
**Implementation status**: Very slow & uneven - States reluctant to devolve power; Panchayats remained weak & ineffective for decades
**Historical roots**: India had panchayats since ancient times (village councils for justice & administration) - British rule weakened them
examTips: Art 40 is a **DPSP** (Part IV) - NOT a Fundamental Right; Non-justiciable
Gandhibased - 'Gram Swaraj' concept; Dr. Ambedkar opposed but Art 40 still included
States were **not legally bound** to implement - Led to non-uniform, weak panchayats till 1992
**Foundation** for 73rd Amendment (1992) which made Panchayats constitutional bodies

events.impact: Provided constitutional basis for village panchayats but implementation left to States' discretion. For 42 years (1950-1992), Art 40 remained largely unimplemented with weak, non-uniform panchayat systems across India.

events.title: Balwant Rai Mehta Committee Report
events.description: First major committee on Panchayati Raj - Recommended 3-tier structure (Gram, Block, District levels)
events.significance: **Blueprint for Panchayati Raj** - First systematic plan for democratic decentralization; Led to establishment of first Panchayati Raj institution in Rajasthan (1959)

details.heading: Key Recommendations & Impact
points: **Background**: Appointed by Govt of India (1957) to examine Community Development Programme & suggest measures for better utilization of resources
**Chairman**: Balwant Rai G. Mehta (Member of Parliament)
**Main Recommendation**: Establish **3-tier Panchayati Raj system** - Gram Panchayat (village), Panchayat Samiti (block), Zila Parishad (district)
**Indirect elections**: Members of higher tiers elected indirectly by lower tiers (not direct elections)
**Functions & finances**: Panchayats should have adequate resources, power, & authority
**Democratic decentralization**: Power should be devolved from State to local bodies
**Organic linkage**: Three tiers should be organically linked with each other
**First implementation**: **Rajasthan** became first State to establish Panchayati Raj (Oct 2, 1959 - Gandhi Jayanti) in **Nagaur district**
**Andhra Pradesh**: Second State to implement (1959)
**Spread**: By mid-1960s, most States had adopted 3-tier structure
examTips: **First committee** on Panchayati Raj - 1957
Recommended **3-tier structure**: Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, Zila Parishad
**Rajasthan first** to implement (Oct 2, 1959) - Nagaur district
**Indirect elections** for higher tiers (unlike 73rd Amendment which mandates direct elections)
Led to implementation of Panchayati Raj across India in 1960s

events.impact: Revolutionary impact - Within 5 years, most States established 3-tier Panchayati Raj. However, by 1970s, panchayats became weak due to: supersession by State govts, lack of funds, irregular elections, political interference. Needed revival.

events.title: Ashok Mehta Committee Report
events.description: Committee to revive declining Panchayati Raj institutions - Recommended 2-tier system & district as focal point
events.significance: **Revival attempt** - Recognized failure of Balwant Rai Mehta's 3-tier system; Recommended major structural changes

details.heading: Key Recommendations & Context
points: **Background**: By 1977, Panchayati Raj institutions had declined drastically - Superseded by State govts, elections not held, funds not released
**Appointed by**: Janata Party government (1977) to suggest measures to strengthen Panchayats
**Chairman**: Ashok Mehta (Senior politician & economist)
**2-tier system**: Recommended **2 tiers only** - Zila Parishad (district) & Mandal Panchayat (covering 8,000-10,000 population) - Eliminate intermediate Panchayat Samiti level
**District as focal point**: Zila Parishad should be the executive body with Mandal Panchayats under it
**Compulsory elections**: Regular elections should be mandatory; State Election Commission should conduct elections
**Reservation**: Seats reserved for SCs/STs in proportion to population
**Financial devolution**: Panchayats should have power to levy taxes & receive adequate State transfers
**Political parties**: Recommended open participation of political parties in panchayat elections
**Constitutional status**: Recommended that Panchayati Raj should be given **constitutional recognition** (later realized through 73rd Amendment)
**Implementation**: Very few States implemented Ashok Mehta recommendations; Karnataka & Andhra Pradesh adopted some provisions; Most States retained 3-tier structure
examTips: **Second major committee** (1977) - After Balwant Rai Mehta (1957)
Recommended **2-tier system** (not 3-tier): Zila Parishad + Mandal Panchayat
**District as focal point** - Executive body
First to recommend **constitutional status** for Panchayats (realized in 1992 via 73rd Amendment)
Recommended **compulsory elections** & State Election Commission (both included in 73rd Amendment)
**Limited implementation** - Few States adopted recommendations

events.impact: Limited immediate impact (few States implemented) BUT laid groundwork for 73rd Amendment. Key ideas adopted in 1992: Constitutional status, compulsory elections, State Election Commission, financial devolution, SC/ST reservation.

events.title: G.V.K. Rao Committee (1985) & L.M. Singhvi Committee (1986)
events.description: Two more committees strengthened case for constitutional status to Panchayats
events.significance: Built momentum for constitutional amendment - Highlighted need for statutory backing to prevent State govt interference

details.heading: Key Points from Both Committees
points: **G.V.K. Rao Committee (1985)**: Appointed to review rural development programs
• Recommended: District should be unit of planning; Zila Parishad should be strengthened; Panchayats need constitutional status
**L.M. Singhvi Committee (1986)**: Most comprehensive committee on Panchayati Raj before 73rd Amendment
• **Chairman**: Dr. L.M. Singhvi (Jurist & Member of Parliament)
• Recommended: **Constitutional recognition** to Panchayats (Part IX); Hold elections regularly (5 years); Adequate financial resources & taxing powers
• Recommended: **Gram Sabha** as foundation - All adult members of village; Gram Sabha should approve development plans
• Recommended: Reservation for **SCs/STs & Women**; State Election Commission for free & fair elections
• Coined phrase: 'Panchayati Raj is the **Parliament of the Village**'
**Impact**: These committees created strong case for constitutional amendment - Panchayats needed protection from State govt interference via constitutional status
examTips: **G.V.K. Rao (1985)** & **L.M. Singhvi (1986)** - Both recommended constitutional status
**L.M. Singhvi** most important - Comprehensive recommendations, many adopted in 73rd Amendment
L.M. Singhvi coined: **'Parliament of the Village'**
Recommended: Gram Sabha, women's reservation, State Election Commission - All included in 73rd Amendment

events.impact: Strong intellectual foundation for 73rd Amendment. L.M. Singhvi Committee's recommendations became blueprint for constitutional amendment. By late 1980s, political consensus emerged on need for constitutional status to Panchayats.

events.title: 64th Amendment Bill (Failed)
events.description: First attempt to grant constitutional status to Panchayats - Passed in Lok Sabha but failed in Rajya Sabha
events.significance: **First failed attempt** - Showed States' reluctance to devolve power; Paved way for successful 73rd Amendment in 1992

details.heading: Details of Failed Amendment
points: **Introduced by**: Rajiv Gandhi government (1989)
**Objective**: Insert new Part IX in Constitution for Panchayati Raj; Make Panchayats constitutional bodies; Mandate regular elections
**Lok Sabha**: **Passed** with required special majority
**Rajya Sabha**: **Failed** to get required special majority - States (represented in RS) opposed as they feared loss of power
**State opposition**: State governments (especially ruled by opposition parties) reluctant to devolve power to Panchayats; Feared loss of control over rural areas & resources
**Key provisions proposed** (similar to later 73rd Amendment):
• 3-tier Panchayati Raj system
• Regular elections every 5 years
• Reservation for SCs/STs
• State Finance Commission for financial devolution
**Why it failed**: Lack of political consensus; States feared erosion of their powers; Rajiv Gandhi government fell shortly after (1989 elections)
examTips: **64th Amendment (1989)** - **FAILED** attempt to give constitutional status to Panchayats
**Passed in Lok Sabha**, **Failed in Rajya Sabha** (States opposed)
Introduced by **Rajiv Gandhi** government
Paved way for **73rd Amendment** (1992) which succeeded under **P.V. Narasimha Rao** government

events.impact: Despite failure, kept Panchayati Raj issue alive. Created awareness about need for constitutional protection. When 64th Amendment failed, pressure mounted on next government to try again. Success came 3 years later.

events.title: 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act 1992 - LANDMARK
events.description: MOST IMPORTANT - Granted constitutional status to Panchayats by inserting Part IX (Art 243-243O) and 11th Schedule (29 subjects)
events.significance: **Game changer** - Panchayats became CONSTITUTIONAL BODIES with mandatory provisions; Ended States' discretion; Largest exercise in democratic decentralization in the world

details.heading: Revolutionary Provisions of 73rd Amendment
points: **Inserted Part IX**: Added Articles **243 to 243O** (16 new articles) covering all aspects of Panchayati Raj
**Inserted 11th Schedule**: Lists **29 subjects** transferred to Panchayats (agriculture, land reforms, minor irrigation, animal husbandry, health, education, etc.)
**Introduced by**: P.V. Narasimha Rao government (1992); **Passed**: Dec 22, 1992; **Effective**: April 24, 1993 (after 50% States ratified)
**MANDATORY PROVISIONS** (States MUST implement):
• **3-tier structure** (Art 243C): Gram Panchayat (village), Panchayat Samiti/Taluk/Block Panchayat (intermediate), Zila Parishad (district)
• **Exception**: States with population < 20 lakh can have 2-tier (no intermediate level)
• **Direct elections** (Art 243K): All members directly elected by people (unlike earlier indirect elections)
• **5-year term** (Art 243E): Panchayats have fixed 5-year term; Fresh elections within 6 months if dissolved
• **1/3rd seats for women** (Art 243D(3)): Revolutionary - Including chairperson posts; First time such large-scale political reservation for women
• **SC/ST reservation** (Art 243D): In proportion to their population in Panchayat area
• **OBC reservation** (Art 243D(6)): States may provide (optional); Many States have implemented
• **State Election Commission** (Art 243K): Independent body to conduct Panchayat elections; Not under State govt control
• **State Finance Commission** (Art 243I): Constituted every 5 years to review financial position of Panchayats & recommend devolution
• **Gram Sabha** (Art 243A): Village assembly of all adult members; Foundation of Panchayati Raj; Powers defined by State law
examTips: **73rd Amendment 1992** - MOST IMPORTANT for exams
**Part IX inserted**: Art **243 to 243O** (16 articles)
**11th Schedule inserted**: **29 subjects** for Panchayats
**Effective**: April 24, **1993** (after ratification by 50% States)
**Mandatory**: 3-tier, Direct elections, 5-year term, 1/3rd women, SC/ST reservation, State Election Commission, State Finance Commission, Gram Sabha
**Revolutionary**: Largest democratic decentralization; Panchayats became constitutional bodies
**P.V. Narasimha Rao** government passed it (1992)

events.impact: REVOLUTIONARY - 3 million elected representatives in Panchayats (1 million women); Panchayats conduct local governance across rural India; Women's political participation increased dramatically; Democratic decentralization at unprecedented scale. BUT: Implementation challenges remain (funds, functions, functionaries not fully devolved by States).

events.title: 11th Schedule - 29 Subjects Transferred to Panchayats
events.description: List of 29 subjects on which Panchayats can make plans and implement schemes
events.significance: Defines **functional domain** of Panchayats - Agriculture to rural housing, education to health - Comprehensive rural governance

details.heading: All 29 Subjects (11th Schedule)
points: **11th Schedule inserted** by 73rd Amendment (similar to 7th Schedule for Union-State-Concurrent)
**29 subjects listed** (States must devolve these to Panchayats as per State law):
1. **Agriculture**, including agricultural extension
2. **Land improvement**, implementation of land reforms, land consolidation, soil conservation
3. **Minor irrigation**, water management, watershed development
4. **Animal husbandry**, dairying, poultry
5. **Fisheries**
6. **Social forestry** & farm forestry
7. **Minor forest produce**
8. **Small scale industries**, including food processing
9. **Khadi, village & cottage industries**
10. **Rural housing**
11. **Drinking water**
12. **Fuel & fodder**
13. **Roads, culverts, bridges, ferries, waterways** - other means of communication
14. **Rural electrification**, including distribution of electricity
15. **Non-conventional energy sources**
16. **Poverty alleviation programs**
17. **Education**, including primary & secondary schools
18. **Technical training & vocational education**
19. **Adult & non-formal education**
20. **Libraries**
21. **Cultural activities**
22. **Markets & fairs**
23. **Health & sanitation**, including hospitals, primary health centers, dispensaries
24. **Family welfare**
25. **Women & child development**
26. **Social welfare**, including welfare of handicapped & mentally retarded
27. **Welfare of weaker sections**, particularly SCs & STs
28. **Public distribution system**
29. **Maintenance of community assets**
examTips: **11th Schedule** has **29 subjects** (NOT 30, NOT 25 - memorize exact number)
Covers: Agriculture, Education, Health, Rural development, Minor irrigation, Drinking water, Roads, Poverty alleviation, Women & child development, Social welfare
**State must devolve** - But extent of devolution varies by State
Similar to **12th Schedule** (74th Amendment) which has **18 subjects** for Urban Local Bodies

events.impact: Empowered Panchayats functionally. BUT: Most States have NOT fully devolved all 29 subjects. On average, only 15-20 subjects devolved. Funds, functions, functionaries (3Fs) not fully transferred - Main criticism of Panchayati Raj implementation.

events.title: PESA Act 1996 - Extension to Scheduled Areas
events.description: Extended Panchayati Raj to 5th Schedule areas with special provisions for tribal autonomy - Gram Sabha is supreme
events.significance: **Tribal self-governance** - Recognizes tribal traditions; Gram Sabha has veto power over development projects; Protects tribal land & resources

details.heading: Key Provisions of PESA Act 1996
points: **Full name**: The Provisions of the Panchayats (Extension to Scheduled Areas) Act, 1996
**Background**: 73rd Amendment (Art 243M(4)(b)) **excluded** 5th Schedule areas from its purview; PESA extends Panchayats to these areas but with tribal safeguards
**Coverage**: Applies to **5th Schedule Scheduled Areas** in 10 States (Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Rajasthan, Telangana)
**Gram Sabha is supreme** (Most important feature):
• **Art 4(d)**: Every village shall have a Gram Sabha consisting of all adult members
• Gram Sabha is **foundation** of Panchayati Raj in Scheduled Areas - Not just advisory
• **Mandatory consultation**: State must consult Gram Sabha before land acquisition
• Gram Sabha must be consulted on matters related to: **Minor water bodies, Minor minerals, Minor forest produce**
**Land protection** (Art 4(i)):
• Gram Sabha has power to **prevent alienation** of tribal land
• Power to **restore** alienated tribal land to original tribal owner
• Approval of Gram Sabha mandatory before land acquisition in Scheduled Areas
**Mining & licenses** (Art 4(m)(iii)):
• Gram Sabha must **recommend** before grant of prospecting license/mining lease for minor minerals
• Gram Sabha must approve before granting licenses for sale/consumption of intoxicants
**Development plans**: Panchayat at appropriate level must approve plans, programs, projects for social & economic development before implementation
**Control over institutions**: Gram Sabha has control over institutions & functionaries in village across sectors
**Customary rights**: PESA recognizes traditional tribal practices in resource management & dispute resolution
**Reservation**: Chairpersons of Panchayats at village & intermediate level reserved for STs; ST reservation in all Panchayats
examTips: **PESA 1996** - Extends Panchayats to **5th Schedule areas**
**Gram Sabha is SUPREME** - Most important point; Mandatory consultation on land, resources, development
**Land protection**: Can prevent alienation & restore alienated tribal land
**Mining approval**: Gram Sabha must recommend for minor mineral licenses
**10 States** covered (5th Schedule States)
**NOT applicable to 6th Schedule** areas (they have Autonomous District Councils - ADCs)
**Slow implementation** - States reluctant; Gram Sabha meetings not held regularly

events.impact: Empowered tribal communities in 5th Schedule areas. Gram Sabha got veto power over projects affecting tribal land & resources. BUT: Implementation very weak - Gram Sabha meetings not held regularly, consultation often superficial, land alienation continues. Forest Rights Act 2006 further strengthened tribal rights.

data.summary: Panchayati Raj evolution: **Art 40 DPSP (1950)** laid foundation but non-justiciable. **Balwant Rai Mehta Committee (1957)** recommended 3-tier system - Rajasthan first to implement (1959). By 1970s, panchayats declined. **Ashok Mehta Committee (1977)** recommended revival & constitutional status. **64th Amendment (1989)** failed in Rajya Sabha. **73rd Amendment (1992)** - LANDMARK - Granted constitutional status by inserting Part IX (Art 243-243O) & 11th Schedule (29 subjects). Mandatory: 3-tier, direct elections, 5-year term, 1/3rd women, SC/ST reservation, State Election Commission, Gram Sabha. Effective April 24, 1993. Revolutionary - 3 million elected representatives (1 million women). **PESA Act (1996)** extended to 5th Schedule areas with tribal safeguards - Gram Sabha supreme, can prevent land alienation. Exam focus: 73rd Amendment provisions (Part IX, 11th Schedule, mandatory features), PESA (Gram Sabha powers), comparison with 74th Amendment (Urban Local Bodies).
